programme.desc: The long-lost underground bunker of Adolf Hitler is home to some of the greatest secrets of the Nazi regime; now, experts use cutting-edge technology to discover new evidence of Hitler's evil vision for global domination.

programme.title: Unearthed
programme.desc: Experts investigate the mysteries of the Bermuda Triangle using cutting-edge technology; as new discoveries reveal alien phenomena at the bottom of the ocean floor, researchers may finally uncover the truth behind this strange place.

programme.title: Unearthed
programme.desc: The lost city of Baiae was the Las Vegas of the ancient world, until a mysterious calamity caused it to sink into the sea; new discoveries reveal the secrets of this sin city that, like Pompeii, some experts believe was destroyed by a supervolcano.

programme.title: Unearthed
programme.desc: The secrets of the world's oldest sunken city are lost to history, but hi-tech underwater archaeology answers questions that books cannot; experts explore sunken ruins and reveal new discoveries about one of the first great empires.

programme.title: Lost Cities of the Jungle
programme.desc: Archaeologists scan the uncharted jungles of Southeast Asia to uncover the rise and fall of the medieval Khmer Empire.

programme.title: Unearthed
programme.desc: Archaeologists decode cryptic inscriptions and use innovative geophysical analysis to reveal the secrets of Mount Nemrut in southeastern Turkey.

programme.title: Outrageous Acts of Science
programme.desc: Tattoo machine; building an engine out of paper; a giant swing.

programme.title: Outrageous Acts of Science
programme.desc: Separating scientific fact from science fiction; testing the limits of paper; selfie with a tornado; giant, ornery alligators roaming around on golf courses.

programme.title: NASA's Unexplained Files
programme.desc: Neil Armstrong enters an unexplained spin; an Apollo 17 photo seems to show a US military outpost on the Moon; possible alien life swimming in the oceans of Jupiter's moons.

programme.title: How the Universe Works
programme.sub-title: Birth of the Monster Black Holes
programme.desc: New discoveries reveal an astonishing supermassive black hole that was born during the earliest days of the cosmos, and finding out how this giant grew so large so quickly may help to explain the very formation of the universe itself.

programme.title: How the Universe Works
programme.desc: White dwarfs are small, dead stars with a dangerous side, and they are capable of exploding into supernovas and destroying planets; new research suggests these mysterious phenomena may be the key to understanding the universe itself.

programme.title: Underground Marvels
programme.desc: The world's biggest labyrinth is a 1,553-mile cave system that's home to some of history's darkest mysteries, and new discoveries at this strange place reveal the long-lost secrets of Nazi occupation, Soviet revolution, and Cold War subterfuge.

programme.title: Saturdays In the South: A History of SEC Football
programme.desc: In the aftermath of the Civil War, America's South is looking to put the past behind it, and finds one path in a growing cultural passion of the North - football. In December 1932, the Southeastern Conference is officially formed.

programme.title: Saturdays In the South: A History of SEC Football
programme.desc: Multiple SEC schools claim national titles from the 1930s through the '50s, including LSU with star running back Billy Cannon in 1958, prior to Cannon's epic game-winning punt return against powerhouse Ole Miss a year later.

programme.title: Saturdays In the South: A History of SEC Football
programme.desc: In the 1960s, as Georgia Tech leaves the conference and the Civil Rights Movement becomes embedded in the history and image of the region, Bear Bryant, hired in 1958, becomes the face of Alabama - and SEC football.

programme.title: Saturdays In the South: A History of SEC Football
programme.desc: As a new decade dawns, quarterbacks Archie Manning, Bert Jones and Condredge Holloway build memorable legacies. Bear Bryant begins a new run of dominance at Alabama, and the rise of television sports transforms the SEC.

programme.title: Saturdays In the South: A History of SEC Football
programme.desc: The 1980s begin with Herschel Walker leading Georgia to a national title as a freshman. After Bear Bryant retires in 1982 and passes away four weeks later, control of the SEC is eventually transferred to Pat Dye and Bo Jackson at Auburn.

programme.title: Saturdays In the South: A History of SEC Football
programme.desc: The 1990s bring change, with expansion and the sport's first-ever conference championship game. Florida's Steve Spurrier fashions an era of high-octane offense, and his Gators form a rivalry with Tennessee and QB Peyton Manning.

programme.title: Saturdays In the South: A History of SEC Football
programme.desc: Nick Saban comes to LSU in 2000 and eventually wins the Tigers' first national championship since 1958 - a feat matched by Les Miles. At Florida, Tim Tebow becomes a cult hero and wins two national titles with Urban Meyer's Gators.

programme.title: Saturdays In the South: A History of SEC Football
programme.desc: The SEC has a run of seven straight national titles, and nine in 12 years. Expansion in 2012 gives the conference 14 schools. Meanwhile, Nick Saban arguably becomes the greatest coach in the history of college football.

programme.title: TrueSouth
programme.desc: Greek natives and their kin built the Birmingham restaurant scene, from barbecue joints to hotdog stands to steakhouses. Bright Star, founded in 1907, is the old guard and Johnny's is the new guard Greek restaurant.

programme.title: TrueSouth
programme.desc: Pablo Rivadeneyra rotisserie-cooks lime-marinated chicken. Larry and Betty Jean Scott work a smoke-belching pit at Scott's BBQ. In these two places, we get a glimpse of the hard work that defines life in the South.

programme.title: TrueSouth
programme.desc: Sands, the soul food café, cooks oxtails and cabbage and ropy okra; Arnold's Country Kitchen, Kahlil Arnold dishes created corn, hashed turnip greens, and fried green tomatoes; the differences between black and white cooking come into focus.

programme.title: TrueSouth
programme.desc: Herby K's is a 1936 vintage beer garden and fry house. Lucky Palace serves wol-fried-t-bones and pork egg foo young. Both of these restaurants are survivors, like Shreveport itself.

programme.title: TrueSouth
programme.desc: If you're a local of New Orleans, you might recognize West African borrowings in music and food but Italian New Orleans has been largely forgotten.

programme.title: TrueSouth
programme.desc: This is a story about a scrappy onetime oil boomtown, where cooks make the most of scraps and the oppressiveness of brisket and how popular narratives have obscured two Gulf Coast dishes that manage to hang on.

programme.title: TrueSouth
programme.desc: In the southern towns of Hodgenville and Bardstown, Kentucky, conflicting ideas about identity and purpose come into focus. In these Southern towns, onion burgers and country sausage prove constants in a time of great change.

programme.title: TrueSouth
programme.desc: Just as there are many Souths, black Memphis reveals itself to be varied and complex and beautiful, Here, we see the streets of Memphis and its classic spots Pop's Hot Tamales, Lee Crumb, and Ms. Girlee's.

programme.title: TrueSouth
